Dear Todd,

 

I am reading the following books, but maybe not as fast as y=
ou would expect
me to.

 

1.	JUnit Recipes, By J.B Raisenberger
2.	Pragmat=
ic Unit Testing in Java with JUnit, by Andrew Hunt and David
Thomas
3.	JUni=
t in Action, by Vincent Massol
4.	Extreme Programming with Ant, by Niemeyer=
 Poteet.

 

I would welcome any suggestions, by you as well. My Java exper=
ience is only
school, and 3 months at my previous job. So if my questions a=
re at a level
lower then you would expect to see, 

Then please let me know=
, I'll look elsewhere. And I do appreciate your
criticism, I will look more=
 into the books first before asking any question.

 

Thanks,

-Kamal.

 

=

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Be=

ogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] testing switch statements in method

=E9dric Beust wrote:
> I think Kamal made it clear that changing the API wa=
s not an 
> option, so he's definitely looking for an option to test an 
> =
API that he has no control over.  Sad, but fairly common in 
> my opinion.
=
> 
> It's already been done, but I'll repeat it:  Michael 
> Feather's book=
 "Testing legacy code" contains some good 
> advice for these kinds of situ=
ations

ever purchased =
and read any of the testing related 
books already recommended to him in th=
e past on this 
list.  So, your recommendation will likely fall on 
deaf ea=
rs.
